text: A man named Job lived in Uz. He was a man of integrity: He was decent, he feared God, and he stayed away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: He owned 7,000 sheep and goats, 3,000 camels, 1,000 oxen, 500 donkeys, and a large number of servants. He was the most influential person in the Middle East.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons used to go to each other’s homes, where they would have parties. (Each brother took his turn having a party.) They would send someone to invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they finished having their parties, Job would send for them in order to cleanse them from sin. He would get up early in the morning and sacrifice burnt offerings for each of them. Job thought, “My children may have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Job offered sacrifices for them all the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when the sons of God came to stand in front of the Lord, Satan the Accuser came along with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord asked Satan, “Where have you come from?”
Satan answered the Lord, “From wandering all over the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord asked Satan, “Have you thought about my servant Job? No one in the world is like him! He is a man of integrity: He is decent, he fears God, and he stays away from evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Satan answered the Lord, “Haven’t you given Job a reason to fear God?
speaker: Narrator

text: Haven’t you put a protective fence around him, his home, and everything he has? You have blessed everything he does. His cattle have spread out over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now stretch out your hand, and strike everything he has. I bet he’ll curse you to your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord told Satan, “Everything he has is in your power, but you must not lay a hand on him!”
Then Satan left the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when Job’s sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s home,
speaker: Narrator

text: a messenger came to Job. He said, “While the oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,
speaker: Narrator

text: men from Sheba attacked. They took the livestock and massacred the servants. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “A fire from God fell from heaven and completely burned your flocks and servants. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three companies and made a raid on the camels. They took the camels and massacred the servants. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “Your sons and your daughters were eating and drinking wine at their oldest brother’s home
speaker: Narrator

text: when suddenly a great storm swept across the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It fell on the young people, and they died. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job stood up, tore his robe in grief, and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground and worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said,
“Naked I came from my mother,
and naked I will return.
The Lord has given,
and the Lord has taken away!
May the name of the Lord be praised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Through all this Job did not sin or blame God for doing anything wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when the sons of God came to stand in front of the Lord, Satan the Accuser came along with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord asked Satan, “Where have you come from?”
Satan answered the Lord, “From wandering all over the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord asked Satan, “Have you thought about my servant Job? No one in the world is like him! He is a man of integrity: He is decent, he fears God, and he stays away from evil. And he still holds on to his principles. You’re trying to provoke me into ruining him for no reason.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Satan answered the Lord, “Skin for skin! Certainly, a man will give everything he has for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch out your hand, and strike his flesh and bones. I bet he’ll curse you to your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Satan, “He is in your power, but you must spare his life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Satan left the Lord’s presence and struck Job with painful boils from the soles of his feet to the top of his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job took a piece of broken pottery to scratch himself as he sat in the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wife asked him, “Are you still holding on to your principles? Curse God and die!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to her, “You’re talking like a godless fool. We accept the good that God gives us. Shouldn’t we also accept the bad?”
Through all this Job’s lips did not utter one sinful word.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Job’s three friends heard about all the terrible things that had happened to him, each of them came from his home—Eliphaz of Teman, Bildad of Shuah, Zophar of Naama. They had agreed they would go together to sympathize with Job and comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw him from a distance, they didn’t even recognize him. They cried out loud and wept, and each of them tore his own clothes in grief. They threw dust on their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sat down on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him because they saw that he was in such great pain.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all this, Job finally opened his mouth and cursed the day he was born.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Scratch out the day I was born
and the night that said, ‘A boy has been conceived!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That day—
let it be pitch-black.
Let God above not even care about it.
Let no light shine on it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the darkness and long shadows claim it as their own.
Let a dark cloud hang over it.
Let the gloom terrify it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That night—
let the blackness take it away.
Let it not be included in the days of the year
or be numbered among the months.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let that night be empty.
Let no joyful singing be heard in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let those who curse the day 
(those who know how to wake up Leviathan)
curse that night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let its stars turn dark before dawn.
Let it hope for light and receive none.
Let it not see the first light of dawn
speaker: Narrator

text:
because it did not shut the doors of the womb from which I came
or hide my eyes from trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why didn’t I die as soon as I was born
and breathe my last breath when I came out of the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did knees welcome me?
Why did breasts let me nurse?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead of being alive,
I would now be quietly lying down.
I would now be sleeping peacefully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would be with the kings and the counselors of the world
who built for themselves what are now ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would be with princes
who had gold,
who filled their homes with silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would be buried like a stillborn baby.
I would not exist.
I would be like infants who never saw the light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the wicked stop their raging.
There the weary are able to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the captives have no troubles at all.
There they do not hear the shouting of the slave driver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There you find both the unimportant and important people.
There the slave is free from his master.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why give light to one in misery
and life to those who find it so bitter,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to those who long for death but it never comes—
though they dig for it more than for buried treasure?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are ecstatic,
delighted to find the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why give light to those whose paths have been hidden,
to those whom God has fenced in?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When my food is in front of me, I sigh.
I pour out my groaning like water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What I fear most overtakes me.
What I dread happens to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have no peace!
I have no quiet!
I have no rest!
And trouble keeps coming!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz from Teman replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If someone tries to talk to you, will you become impatient?
But who can keep from talking?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, you have instructed many people:
When hands were weak, you made them strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When someone stumbled, you lifted him up with your words.
When knees were weak, you gave them strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But trouble comes to you, and you’re impatient.
It touches you, and you panic.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doesn’t your fear of God give you confidence
and your lifetime of integrity give you hope?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now think about this:
Which innocent person ever died an untimely death?
Find me a decent person who has been destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whenever I saw those who plowed wickedness and planted misery,
they gathered its harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God destroys them with his breath
and kills them with a blast of his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though the roar of the lion
and the growl of the ferocious lion is loud,
the young lions have had their teeth knocked out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The old lions die without any prey to eat,
and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I was told something secretly
and heard something whispered in my ear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With disturbing thoughts from visions in the night,
when deep sleep falls on people,
speaker: Narrator

text:
fear and trembling came over me,
and all my bones shook.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A spirit passed in front of me.
It made my hair stand on end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Something stood there.
I couldn’t tell what it was.
A vague image was in front of my eyes.
I heard a soft voice:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Can any mortal be righteous to God?
Can any human being be pure to his maker?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You see, God doesn’t trust his own servants,
and he accuses his angels of making mistakes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much more will he accuse those who live in clay houses
that have their foundation in the dust.
Those houses can be crushed quicker than a moth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
From morning to evening, they are shattered.
They will disappear forever without anyone paying attention.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Haven’t the ropes of their tent been loosened?
Won’t they die without wisdom?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Cry out!
Is there anyone to answer you?
To which of the holy ones will you turn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, anger kills a stubborn fool,
and jealousy murders a gullible person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen a stubborn fool take root,
but I quickly cursed his house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His children are far from help.
They are crushed at the city gate,
and no one is there to rescue them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What a stubborn fool gathers, hungry people eat.
They take it even from among the thorns,
and thirsty people pant after his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, sorrow doesn’t come from the soil,
and trouble doesn’t sprout from the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a person is born for trouble as surely as sparks fly up from a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But I would seek God’s help
and present my case to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does great things that we cannot understand
and miracles that we cannot count.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gives rain to the earth
and sends water to the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He places lowly people up high.
He lifts those who mourn to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He keeps shrewd people from carrying out their plans
so that they cannot do anything successfully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He catches the wise with their own tricks.
The plans of schemers prove to be hasty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the daytime they meet darkness
and grope in the sunlight as if it were night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But he saves other people from their slander
and the needy from the power of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the poor have hope
while wrongdoing shuts its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Blessed is the person whom God corrects.
That person should not despise discipline from the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God injures, but he bandages.
He beats you up, but his hands make you well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will keep you safe from six troubles,
and when the seventh one comes, no harm will touch you:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In famine he will save you from death,
and in war he will save you from the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When the tongue lashes out, you will be safe,
and you will not be afraid of destruction when it comes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You will be able to laugh at destruction and starvation,
so do not be afraid of wild animals on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You will have a binding agreement with the stones in the field,
and wild animals will be at peace with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You will know peace in your tent.
You will inspect your house and find nothing missing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You will find that your children are many
and your descendants are like the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You will come to your grave at a ripe old age
like a stack of hay in the right season.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We have studied all of this thoroughly! This is the way it is.
Listen to it, and learn it for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If only my grief could be weighed,
if only my misery could be laid on the scales with it,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then they would be heavier than the sand of the seas.
I spoke carelessly
speaker: Narrator

text:
because the arrows of the Almighty have found their target in me,
and my spirit is drinking their poison.
God’s terrors line up in battle against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Does a wild donkey bray when it’s eating grass,
or does an ox make a sound over its hay?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is tasteless food eaten without salt,
or is there any flavor in the white of an egg?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I refuse to touch such things.
They are disgusting to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How I wish that my prayer would be answered—
that God would give me what I’m hoping for,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that God would finally be willing to crush me,
that he would reach out to cut me off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I would still have comfort.
I would be happy despite my endless pain,
because I have not rejected the words of the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What strength do I have left that I can go on hoping?
What goal do I have that I would want to prolong my life?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do I have the strength of rocks?
Does my body have the strength of bronze?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Am I not completely helpless?
Haven’t my skills been taken away from me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“A friend should treat a troubled person kindly,
even if he abandons the fear of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My brothers have been as deceptive as seasonal rivers,
like the seasonal riverbeds that flood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are dark with ice.
They are hidden by snow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They vanish during a scorching summer.
In the heat their riverbeds dry up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They change their course.
They go into a wasteland and disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Caravans from Tema look for them.
Travelers from Sheba search for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are ashamed because they relied on the streams.
Arriving there, they are disappointed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So you are as unreliable to me as they are.
You see something terrifying, and you are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did I ever say, ‘Give me a gift,’
or ‘Offer me a bribe from your wealth,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
or ‘Rescue me from an enemy,’
or ‘Ransom me from a tyrant’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach me, and I’ll be silent.
Show me where I’ve been wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How painful an honest discussion can be!
In correcting me, you correct yourselves!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you think my words need correction?
Do you think they’re what a desperate person says to the wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Would you also throw dice for an orphan?
Would you buy and sell your friend?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now, if you’re willing, look at me.
I won’t lie to your face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please change your mind.
Don’t permit any injustice.
Change your mind because I am still right about this!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there injustice on my tongue,
or is my mouth unable to tell the difference between right and wrong?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Isn’t a mortal’s stay on earth difficult
like a hired hand’s daily work?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a slave, he longs for shade.
Like a hired hand, he eagerly looks for his pay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Likewise, I have been given months that are of no use,
and I have inherited nights filled with misery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I lie down, I ask,
‘When will I get up?’
But the evening is long,
and I’m exhausted from tossing about until dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My body is covered with maggots and scabs.
My skin is crusted over with sores; then they ooze.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days go swifter than a weaver’s shuttle.
They are spent without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember, my life is only a breath,
and never again will my eyes see anything good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that watches over me will no longer see me.
Your eye will look for me, but I’ll be gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a cloud fades away and disappears,
so a person goes into the grave and doesn’t come back again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t come back home again,
and his household doesn’t recognize him anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I won’t keep my mouth shut,
but I will speak from the distress that is in my spirit
and complain about the bitterness in my soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Am I the sea or a sea monster
that you have set a guard over me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I say,
‘My couch may give me comfort.
My bed may help me bear my pain,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
then you frighten me with dreams
and terrify me with visions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My throat would rather be choked.
My body  would prefer death to these dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I hate my life; I do not want to live forever.
Leave me alone because my days are so brief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is a mortal that you should make so much of him,
that you should be concerned about him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is he that you should inspect him every morning
and examine him every moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why don’t you stop looking at me
long enough to let me swallow my spit?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I sin, what can I possibly do to you
since you insist on spying on people?
Why do you make me your target?
I’ve become a burden even to myself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why don’t you forgive my disobedience
and take away my sin?
Soon I’ll lie down in the dust.
Then you will search for me, but I’ll be gone!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad from Shuah replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you say these things?
How long will your words be so windy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does God distort justice,
or does the Almighty distort righteousness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your children sinned against him,
he allowed them to suffer the consequences of their sinfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you search for God
and plead for mercy from the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then what you had in the past will seem small
compared with the great prosperity you’ll have in the future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Ask the people of past generations.
Find out what their ancestors had learned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have only been around since yesterday, and we know nothing.
Our days on earth are only a fleeting shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Won’t their words teach you?
Won’t they share their thoughts with you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can papyrus grow up where there is no swamp?
Can rushes grow tall without water?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if they were fresh and not cut,
they would wither quicker than grass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The same thing happens to all who forget God.
The hope of the godless dies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His confidence is easily shattered.
His trust is a spider’s web.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one leans on his house, it collapses.
If one holds on to it, it will not support his weight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is like a well-watered plant in the sunshine.
The shoots spread over his garden.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its roots weave through a pile of stones.
They cling to a stone house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when it is uprooted from its place,
the ground denies it and says, ‘I never saw you!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is its joy in this life,
and others sprout from the same ground to take its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Certainly, God does not reject a person of integrity
or give a helping hand to wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will fill your mouth with laughter
and your lips with happy shouting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate you will be clothed with shame,
and the tent of the wicked will cease to exist.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yes, I know that this is true.
But how can a mortal be declared righteous to God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he wished to debate with God,
he wouldn’t be able to answer one question in a thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God is wise in heart and mighty in power.
Who could oppose him and win?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He moves mountains without their knowing it,
and he topples them in his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shakes the earth from its place,
and its pillars tremble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He commands the sun not to rise.
He doesn’t let the stars come out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stretches out the heavens by himself
and walks on the waves of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made the constellations Ursa Major, Orion, and the Pleiades,
and the clusters of stars in the south.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does great things that are unsearchable
and miracles that cannot be numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He passes alongside of me, and I don’t even see him.
He goes past me, and I don’t even notice him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He takes something away, but who can stop him?
Who is going to ask him, ‘What are you doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
God does not hold back his anger.
Even Rahab’s helpers bow humbly in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How can I possibly answer God?
How can I find the right words to speak with him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if I were right, I could not answer him.
I would have to plead for mercy from my judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I cried out and he answered me,
I do not believe that he would listen to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He would knock me down with a storm
and bruise me without a reason.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He would not let me catch my breath.
He fills me with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If it is a matter of strength,
then he is the mighty one.
If it is about justice,
who will charge me with a crime?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I am righteous, my own mouth would condemn me.
It would declare that I am corrupt even if I am a man of integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I am a man of integrity, I have no way of knowing it.
I hate my life!
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is all the same.
That is why I say,
‘He destroys both the man of integrity and the wicked.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a sudden disaster brings death,
he makes fun of the despair of innocent people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth is handed over to the wicked.
He covers the faces of its judges.
If he isn’t the one doing this, who is?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My days go by more quickly than a runner.
They sprint away.
They don’t see anything good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They pass by quickly like boats made from reeds,
like an eagle swooping down on its prey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if I say, ‘I will forget my complaining;
I will change my expression and smile,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I still dread everything I must suffer.
I know that you won’t declare me innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve already been found guilty.
Why should I work so hard for nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I wash myself with lye soap
and cleanse my hands with bleach,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then you would plunge me into a muddy pit,
and my own clothes would find me disgusting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A human like me cannot answer God,
‘Let’s take our case to court.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no mediator between us
to put his hand on both of us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God should take his rod away from me,
and he should not terrify me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I would speak and not be afraid of him.
But I know that I am not like that.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I hate my life.
I will freely express my complaint.
I will speak as bitterly as I feel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will say to God,
‘Don’t condemn me.
Let me know why you are quarreling with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you gain by mistreating me,
by rejecting the work of your hands
while you favor the plans of the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you actually have human eyes?
Do you see as a mortal sees?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are your days like a mortal’s days?
Are your years like a human’s years?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is that why you look for guilt in me
and search for sin in me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You know I’m not guilty,
but there is no one to rescue me from your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘Your hands formed me and made every part of me,
then you turned to destroy me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please remember that you made me out of clay
and that you will return me to the dust again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Didn’t you pour me out like milk
and curdle me like cheese?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Didn’t you dress me in skin and flesh
and weave me together with bones and tendons?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You gave me life and mercy.
Your watchfulness has preserved my spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But in your heart you hid these things.
I know this is what you did.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘If I sin, you watch me
and will not free me from my guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How terrible it will be for me if I’m guilty!
Even if I’m righteous, I dare not lift up my head.
I am filled with disgrace
while I look on my misery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a proud, ferocious lion you hunt me down.
You keep working your miracles against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You keep finding new witnesses against me.
You keep increasing your anger toward me.
You keep bringing new armies against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘Why did you take me out of the womb?
I wish I had breathed my last breath
before anyone had laid eyes on me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then it would be as if I had never existed,
as if I had been carried from the womb to the tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“ ‘Isn’t my life short enough?
So stop this, and leave me alone.
Let me smile a little
speaker: Narrator

text:
before I go away
to a land of darkness and gloom,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to a dismal land of long shadows and confusion
where light is as bright as darkness.
I’ll never return.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zophar from Naama replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Shouldn’t someone answer this flood of words?
Should a good public speaker be acquitted?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should your empty talk silence others
so that you can make fun of us without any shame?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You say, ‘My teaching is morally correct,’
and, ‘As you can see, I’m innocent.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I only wish God would speak
and open his mouth to talk to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He would tell you the secrets of wisdom,
because true wisdom is twice as great as your wisdom,
and you would know that God forgets your sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you discover God’s hidden secrets,
or are you able to find the Almighty’s limits?
speaker: Narrator

text:
God’s wisdom is higher than heaven.
What can you do?
It is deeper than the depths of hell.
What can you know?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is longer than the earth
and wider than the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If God comes along and imprisons someone
and then calls a court into session, who can stop him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He knows who the scoundrels are.
And when he sees sin, doesn’t he pay attention to it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But an empty-headed person will gain understanding
when a wild donkey is born tame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you want to set your heart right,
then pray to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you’re holding on to sin, put it far away,
and don’t let injustice live in your tent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will be able to show your face without being ashamed,
and you will be secure and unafraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will forget your misery
and remember it like water that has flowed downstream.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then your life will be brighter than the noonday sun.
The darkness in your life will become like morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will feel confident because there’s hope,
and you will look around and rest in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will lie down with no one to frighten you,
and many people will try to gain your favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the wicked will lose their eyesight.
Their escape route will be closed.
Their only hope is to take their last breath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You certainly are wise people,
and when you die, wisdom will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like you, I have a mind.
I am not inferior to you.
But who doesn’t know these things?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a laughingstock to my neighbors.
I am one who calls on God and expects an answer.
A man of integrity, a man who is righteous, has become a laughingstock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“A person who has an easy life has no appreciation for misfortune.
He thinks it is the fate of those who slip up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But robbers’ tents are prosperous,
and there is security for those who provoke God,
for those whose god is their power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Instead, ask the animals, and they will teach you.
Ask the birds, and they will tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or speak with the earth, and it will teach you.
Even the fish will relate the story to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: What creature doesn’t know that the Lord’s hands made it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The life of every living creature
and the spirit in every human body are in his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doesn’t the ear distinguish sounds
and the tongue taste food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Wisdom is with the ancient one.
The one who has had many days has insight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has wisdom and strength.
Advice and insight are his.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he tears something down, it cannot be rebuilt.
When he puts someone in prison, that person cannot be freed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he holds back the waters, there is a drought.
When he releases them, they flood the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God has power and priceless wisdom.
He owns both the deceiver and the person who is deceived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads counselors away barefoot
and makes fools out of judges.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He loosens kings’ belts
and strips them of their pants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads priests away barefoot
and misleads those who serve in a temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes trusted advisers unable to speak
and takes away the good judgment of respected leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He pours contempt on influential people
and unbuckles the belt of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He uncovers mysteries hidden in the darkness
and brings gloom into the light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes nations important and then destroys them.
He makes nations large and leads them away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He takes away the common sense of a country’s leaders
and makes them stumble about in a pathless wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They grope in the dark with no light,
and he makes them stumble like drunks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My eye has certainly seen all of this!
My ear has heard and understood it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After all, I know it as well as you do.
I am not inferior to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, I want to speak to the Almighty,
and I wish to argue my case in front of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you are smearing me with lies.
All of you are worthless physicians.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wish you would keep silent.
For you, that would be wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please listen to my argument,
and pay attention to my plea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will you talk wickedly for God
and talk deceitfully on his behalf?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you favor him
as if you were arguing in court on God’s behalf?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it go well when he cross-examines you?
Will you try to trick him as one mortal tricks another?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he really defend you
if you secretly favor him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doesn’t his majesty terrify you?
Doesn’t the fear of him fall upon you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Your recollections are worthless proverbs.
Your answers are absolutely useless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be quiet, because I want to speak.
Let whatever may happen to me happen!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am biting off more than I can chew
and taking my life in my own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If God would kill me, I would have no hope left.
Nevertheless, I will defend my behavior to his face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This also will be my salvation
because no godless person could face him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen carefully to my words.
Hear my declaration.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have prepared my case.
I know that I will be declared righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can make a case against me?
If someone could, I’d be silent and die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please don’t do two things to me
so that I won’t have to hide from you:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stop oppressing me.
Don’t let your terror frighten me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then call, and I’ll answer.
Otherwise, I’ll speak, and you’ll answer me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How many crimes and sins have I committed?
Make me aware of my disobedience and my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you hide your face from me and consider me your enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are you trying to make a fluttering leaf tremble
or trying to chase dry husks?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You write down bitter accusations against me.
You make me suffer for the sins of my youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You put my feet in shackles.
You follow my trail by engraving marks on the soles of my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am like worn-out wineskins,
like moth-eaten clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A person who is born of a woman is short-lived and is full of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He comes up like a flower; then he withers.
He is like a fleeting shadow; he doesn’t stay long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You observe this
and call me to account to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If only an unclean person could become clean!
It’s not possible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the number of his days
and the number of his months are determined by you,
and you set his limit,
then he cannot go past it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look away from him, and he will cease to be.
Meanwhile, he loves life as a laborer loves work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is hope for a tree when it is cut down.
It will sprout again.
Its shoots will not stop sprouting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If its roots grow old in the ground
and its stump dies in the soil,
speaker: Narrator

text:
merely a scent of water will make it sprout
and grow branches like a plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But a human dies and is powerless.
A person breathes his last breath, and where is he?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As water drains out of a lake,
or as a river dries up completely,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so each person lies down
and does not rise until the heavens cease to exist.
He does not wake up.
He is not awakened from his sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wish you would hide me in Sheol
and keep me hidden there until your anger cools.
Set a specific time for me when you will remember me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If a person dies, will he go on living?
I will wait for my relief to come
as long as my hard labor continues.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will call, and I will answer you.
You will long for the person your hands have made.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though now you count my steps,
you will not keep a record of my sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My disobedience will be closed up in a bag,
and you will cover over my sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As surely as a mountain falls
and rocks are dislodged,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so water wears away stone,
floods wash away soil from the land,
and you destroy a mortal’s hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You overpower him forever, and he passes away.
You change his appearance and send him away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His sons are honored, and he doesn’t know it.
Or they become unimportant, and he doesn’t realize it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He feels only his body’s pain.
He is only worried about himself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz from Teman replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should a wise person answer with endless details
and fill his stomach with the east wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should he argue with words that don’t help,
with speeches that don’t help anyone?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, you destroy the fear of God
and diminish devotion to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your sin teaches you what to say.
You choose to talk with a sly tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your own mouth condemns you, not I.
Your lips testify against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Were you the first human to be born?
Were you delivered before the hills existed?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did you listen in on God’s council meeting
and receive a monopoly on wisdom?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you know that we don’t know?
What do you understand that we don’t?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Both the old and the gray-haired are among us.
They are older than your father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isn’t God’s comfort enough for you,
even when gently spoken to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why have your emotions carried you away?
Why do your eyes flash
speaker: Narrator

text:
when you turn against God
and spit these words out of your mouth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should a mortal be considered faultless
or someone born of a woman be considered righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If God doesn’t trust his holy ones,
and the heavens are not pure in his sight,
speaker: Narrator

text:
how much less will he trust the one who is disgusting and corrupt,
the one who drinks wickedness like water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ll tell you; listen to me!
I’ll relate what I have seen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll tell you what wise people have declared
and what was not kept secret from their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
(The land was given to them alone,
and no stranger passed through their land.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The wicked person is tortured all his days.
Only a few years are reserved for the ruthless person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrifying sounds are in his ears.
While he enjoys peace, the destroyer comes to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t believe he’ll return from the dark.
He is destined to be killed with a sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He wanders around for food and asks, ‘Where is it?’
He knows that his ruin is close at hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The day of darkness troubles him.
Distress and anguish terrify him
like a king ready for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stretches out his hand against God
and attacks the Almighty like a warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stubbornly charges at him with a thick shield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“His face is bloated with fat,
and he is fat around the waist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lives in ruined cities
where no one dwells,
in houses that are doomed to be piles of rubble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He won’t get rich,
and his wealth won’t last.
His possessions won’t spread out over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He won’t escape the darkness.
A flame will shrivel his branches.
He will be blown away by his own breath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shouldn’t trust in worthless things and deceive himself
because he will get worthless things in return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will happen before his time has come,
and his branch will not become green.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will drop his unripened grapes like a vine
and throw off his blossoms like an olive tree
speaker: Narrator

text:
because a mob of godless people produces nothing,
and fire burns up the tents of those who offer bribes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They conceive trouble and give birth to evil.
Their wombs produce deception.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have heard many things like this before.
You are all pathetic at comforting me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your long-winded speeches never end?
What disturbs you that you keep on answering me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I, too, could speak like you
if we could trade places.
I could string words together against you
and shake my head at you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I could encourage you with my mouth,
and my quivering lips could ease your pain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I speak, my pain is not eased.
If I stop talking, how much of it will go away?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now, God has worn me out.
You, God, have destroyed everyone who supports me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have shriveled me up, which itself is a witness against me.
My frail body rises up and testifies against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God’s anger tore me apart and attacked me.
He gritted his teeth at me.
My opponent looked sharply at me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People ridiculed me with their mouths.
They slapped my cheeks with contempt.
They united against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God handed me over to unjust people
and threw me into the hands of wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was at ease, and he shattered me.
He grabbed me by the back of the neck and smashed my skull.
He set me up as his target,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and his archers surrounded me.
He slashes open my kidneys without mercy
and spills my blood on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He inflicts wound after wound on me.
He lunges at me like a warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have sewn sackcloth over my skin,
and I have thrown my strength in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My face is red from crying,
and dark shadows encircle my eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text:
although my hands have done nothing violent,
and my prayer is sincere.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Earth, don’t cover my blood.
Don’t ever let my cry for justice be stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even now, look! My witness is in heaven,
and the one who testifies for me is above,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the spokesman for my thoughts.
My eyes drip with tears to God
speaker: Narrator

text: because in a few short years I will take the path of no return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But my witness will plead for a human in front of God.
The Son of Man will plead for his friend!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My spirit is broken.
My days have been snuffed out.
The cemetery is waiting for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, mockers are around me.
My eyes are focused on their opposition.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please guarantee my bail yourself.
Who else will guarantee it with a handshake?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have closed their minds so that they cannot understand.
That is why you will not honor them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
(Whoever turns in friends to get their property
should have his children’s eyesight fail.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now he has made me a laughingstock for many people.
Now they spit in my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now my eyes are blurred from grief.
Now all my limbs are like a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Decent people are shocked by this,
and it stirs up the innocent against godless people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet, the righteous person clings to his way,
and the one with clean hands grows stronger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now, all of you, come and try again!
I won’t find one wise man among you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days are passing by.
My plans are broken.
My dreams are shattered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You say that night is day.
Light has nearly become darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I look for the grave as my home
and make my bed in the darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I say to the pit, ‘You are my father,’
and to the worm, ‘You are my mother and sister,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
then where is my hope?
Can you see any hope left in me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will hope go down with me to the gates of the grave?
Will my hope rest with me in the dust?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad from Shuah replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long before your words will end?
Think it through, and then we’ll talk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you think of us as cattle?
Why are we considered stupid in your eyes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you rip yourself apart in anger?
Should the earth be abandoned for your sake
or a boulder be dislodged?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, the light of the wicked is snuffed out.
The flame of his fire stops glowing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The light in his tent becomes dark,
and the lamp above him is snuffed out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“His healthy stride is shortened,
and his own planning trips him up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His own feet get him tangled in a net
as he walks around on its webbing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A trap catches his heel.
A snare holds him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A rope is hidden on the ground for him.
A trap is on his path to catch him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Terrors suddenly pounce on him from every side
and chase him every step he takes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hunger undermines his strength.
Disaster is waiting beside him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His skin is eaten away by disease.
Death’s firstborn son eats away at the limbs of his body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is dragged from the safety of his tent
and marched off to the king of terrors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire lives in his tent.
Sulfur is scattered over his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His roots dry up under him.
His branches wither over him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All memory about him will vanish from the earth,
and his reputation will not be known on the street corner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will be driven from the light into the dark
and chased out of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not have any children or descendants among his people
or any survivor where he used to live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People in the west are shocked by what happens to him.
People in the east are seized with horror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what happens to the homes of wicked people
and to those who do not know God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you torment me
and depress me with words?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have insulted me ten times now.
You’re not even ashamed of mistreating me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if it were true that I’ve made a mistake without realizing it,
my mistake would affect only me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are trying to make yourselves look better than me
by using my disgrace as an argument against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then I want you to know that God has wronged me
and surrounded me with his net.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, I cry, ‘Help! I’m being attacked!’ but I get no response.
I call for help, but there is no justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God has blocked my path so that I can’t go on.
He has made my paths dark.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has stripped me of my honor.
He has taken the crown off my head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He beats me down on every side until I’m gone.
He uproots my hope like a tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is very angry at me.
He considers me to be his enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His troops assemble against me.
They build a ramp to attack me
and camp around my tent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My brothers stay far away from me.
My friends are complete strangers to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My relatives and my closest friends have stopped coming.
My house guests have forgotten me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My female slaves consider me to be a stranger.
I am like a foreigner to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I call my slave, but he doesn’t answer, though I beg him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My breath offends my wife.
I stink to my own children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even young children despise me.
If I stand up, they make fun of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All my closest friends are disgusted with me.
Those I love have turned against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am skin and bones,
and I have escaped only by the skin of my teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have pity on me, my friends!
Have pity on me because God’s hand has struck me down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you pursue me as God does?
Why are you never satisfied with my flesh?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I wish now my words were written.
I wish they were inscribed on a scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wish they were forever engraved on a rock
with an iron stylus and lead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I know that my defender lives,
and afterwards, he will rise on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even after my skin has been stripped off my body,
I will see God in my own flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will see him with my own eyes,
not with someone else’s.
My heart fails inside me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You say,
‘We will persecute him!
The root of the problem is found in him.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear death,
because your anger is punishable by death.
Then you will know there is a judge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zophar from Naama replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My disturbing thoughts make me answer,
and because of them I am upset.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have heard criticism that makes me ashamed,
but a spirit beyond my understanding gives me answers.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
the triumph of the wicked is short-lived,
and the joy of the godless person lasts only a moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If his height reaches to the sky
and his head touches the clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he will certainly rot like his own feces.
Those who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will fly away like a dream and not be found.
He will be chased away like a vision in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eyes that saw him will see him no more.
His home will not look at him again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His children will have to ask the poor for help.
His own hands will have to give back his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones, once full of youthful vigor,
will lie down with him in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Though evil is sweet in his mouth
and he hides it under his tongue….
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he savors it and won’t let go of it
and he holds it on the roof of his mouth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the food in his belly turns sour.
It becomes snake venom in his stomach.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He vomits up the riches that he swallowed.
God forces them out of his stomach.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godless person sucks the poison of snakes.
A viper’s fang kills him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He won’t be able to drink from the streams
or from the rivers of honey and buttermilk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will give back what he earned without enjoying it.
He will get no joy from the profits of his business
speaker: Narrator

text:
because he crushed and abandoned the poor.
He has taken by force a house that he didn’t build.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will never know peace in his heart.
He will never allow anything he desires to escape his grasp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Nothing is left for him to eat.
His prosperity won’t last.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even with all his wealth
the full force of misery comes down on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let that misery fill his belly.
God throws his burning anger at the godless person and makes his wrath come down on him like rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If that person flees from an iron weapon,
a bronze bow will pierce him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He pulls it out, and it comes out of his back.
The glittering point comes out of his gallbladder. 
“Terrors come quickly to the godless person:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Total darkness waits in hiding for his treasure.
A fire that no one fans will burn him.
Whatever is left in his tent will be devoured.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Heaven exposes his sin.
Earth rises up against him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A flood will sweep away his house,
a flash flood on the day of his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the reward God gives to the wicked person,
the inheritance God has appointed for him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen carefully to my words,
and let that be the comfort you offer me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bear with me while I speak.
Then after I’ve spoken, you may go on mocking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Am I complaining about a person?
Why shouldn’t I be impatient?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at me, and be shocked,
and put your hand over your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I remember it, I’m terrified,
and shuddering seizes my body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why do the wicked go on living, grow old,
and even become more powerful?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They see their children firmly established with them,
and they get to see their descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their homes are free from fear,
and God doesn’t use his rod on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their bulls are fertile when they breed.
Their cows give birth to calves and never miscarry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They send their little children out to play
like a flock of lambs,
and their children dance around.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sing with the tambourine and lyre,
and they are happy with the music of the flute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spend their days in happiness,
and they go peacefully to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they say to God,
‘Leave us alone.
We don’t want to know your ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is the Almighty that we should serve him?
What do we gain if we pray to him?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyhow, isn’t their happiness in their own power?
(The plan of the wicked is foreign to my way of thinking.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How often is the lamp of the wicked snuffed out?
How often does disaster happen to them?
How often does an angry God give them pain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How often are they like straw in the wind
or like husks that the storm sweeps away?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You say, ‘God saves a person’s punishment for his children.’
God should pay back that person
so that he would know that it is a punishment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes should see his own ruin.
He should drink from the wrath of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can he be interested in his family after he’s gone,
when the number of his months is cut short?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can anyone teach God knowledge?
Can anyone judge the Most High?
speaker: Narrator

text:
One person dies in his prime
and feels altogether happy and contented.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His stomach is full of milk,
and his bones are strong and healthy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Another person, never having tasted happiness,
dies with a bitter soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Together they lie down in the dust,
and worms cover them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You see, I know your thoughts
and the schemes you plot against me
speaker: Narrator

text:
because you ask,
‘Where is the house of the influential person?
Where is the tent where wicked people live?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Haven’t you asked travelers?
But you didn’t pay attention to their directions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the day of disaster the wicked person is spared.
On the day of God’s anger he is rescued.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who will tell him to his face how he lived?
Who will pay him back for what he did?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is carried to the cemetery,
and his grave is guarded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The soil in the creekbed is sweet to him.
Everyone follows him.
Countless others went before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can you comfort me with this nonsense
when your answers continue to betray me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz from Teman replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can a human be of any use to God
when even a wise person is only useful to himself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is the Almighty pleased when you are righteous?
Does he gain anything when you follow the path of integrity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does God correct you
and bring you into a court of law because you fear him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Aren’t you really very wicked?
Is there no end to your wrongdoing?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For no reason you take your brothers’ goods as security for a loan
and strip them of their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You don’t even give a tired person a drink of water,
and you take food away from hungry people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A strong person owns the land.
A privileged person lives in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You send widows away empty-handed,
and the arms of orphans are broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why traps are all around you
and great fear suddenly grips you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why darkness surrounds you and you cannot see
and a flood of water covers you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Isn’t God high above in the heavens?
Look how high the highest stars are!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You ask, ‘What does God know?
Can he judge anything from behind a dark cloud?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thick clouds surround him so that he cannot see.
He walks above the clouds.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Are you following the old path that wicked people have taken?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are snatched up before their time.
A river washes their foundation away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They told God, ‘Leave us alone!
What can the Almighty do for us?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet, he filled their homes with good things.
(The plan of the wicked is foreign to my way of thinking.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous saw it and were glad,
and the innocent made fun of them by saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Indeed, their wealth has been wiped out,
and a fire has burned up what little they had left.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Be in harmony and at peace with God.
In this way you will have prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Accept instruction from his mouth,
and keep his words in your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you return to the Almighty, you will prosper.
If you put wrongdoing out of your tent,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and lay your gold down in the dust,
and put your gold from Ophir among the pebbles in the rivers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then the Almighty will become your gold
and your large supply of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will be happy with the Almighty
and look up toward God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will pray to him, and he will listen to you,
and you will keep your vow to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you promise to do something, you will succeed,
and light will shine on your path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When others are discouraged, you will say, ‘Cheer up!’
Then he will save the humble person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will rescue one who is not innocent.
That person will be rescued by your purity.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My complaint is bitter again today.
I try hard to control my sighing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If only I knew where I could find God!
I would go where he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would present my case to him.
I would have a mouthful of arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I want to know the words he would use to answer me.
I want to understand the things he would say to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Would he sue me and hide behind great legal maneuvers?
No, he certainly would press charges against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then decent people could argue with him,
and I would escape my judgment forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, if I go east, he isn’t there.
If I go west, I can’t find him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I go northward, where he is at work, I can’t observe him.
If I turn southward, I can’t see him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I can’t find him because he knows the road I take.
When he tests me,
I’ll come out as pure as gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have followed his footsteps closely.
I have stayed on his path and did not turn from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have not left his commands behind.
I have treasured his words in my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But God is one of a kind.
Who can make him change his mind?
He does whatever he wants!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will carry out his orders concerning me
as he does with so many other things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why I’m terrified of him.
When I think of it, I’m afraid of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has discouraged me.
The Almighty has filled me with terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I am not silenced by the dark
or by the thick darkness that covers my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why doesn’t the Almighty set aside times for punishment?
Why don’t those who are close to him see his days of judgment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“People move boundary markers.
They steal flocks and tend them as shepherds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They drive away the orphan’s donkey.
They take the widow’s ox as security for a loan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They force needy people off the road.
All the poor people of the country go into hiding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like wild donkeys in the desert,
poor people go out to do their work, looking for food.
The plains provide food for their children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They harvest animal food in the field to feed themselves.
They pick the leftover grapes in the wicked person’s vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All night they lie naked
without a covering from the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are drenched by the rainstorms in the mountains.
They hug the rocks because they can’t find shelter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“People snatch the nursing orphan from a breast
and take a poor woman’s baby as security for a loan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why the poor go around naked.
They are hungry, yet they carry bundles of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They press out olive oil between rows of olive trees.
They stomp on grapes in wine vats, yet they are thirsty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those dying in the city groan.
Wounded people cry for help, but God pays no attention to their prayers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Such people are among those who rebel against the light.
They are not acquainted with its ways.
They do not stay on its paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At dawn murderers rise; they kill the poor and needy.
At night they become thieves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Adulterers watch for twilight.
They say, ‘No one is watching us,’ as they cover their faces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the dark, they break into houses,
but by day they lock themselves in.
They do not even know the light,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because morning and deep darkness are the same to them,
because they are familiar with the terrors of deep darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such people are like scum on the surface of the water.
Their property is cursed in the land.
People do not travel the road that goes to their vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as drought and heat steal water from snow,
so the grave steals people who sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The womb forgets them.
Worms feast on them.
No one remembers them anymore,
and wickedness is snapped like a twig.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These men take advantage of childless women.
These men show no kindness to widows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God will drag away these mighty men by his power.
These people may prosper,
but they will never feel secure about life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God may let them feel confident and self-reliant,
but his eyes are on their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such people may be prosperous for a little while,
but then they’re gone.
They are brought down low and disappear like everything else.
They wither like heads of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If it isn’t so, who can prove I’m a liar
and show that my words are worthless?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad from Shuah replied to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Authority and terror belong to God.
He establishes peace in his high places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there any limit to the number of his troops?
Is there anyone on whom his light does not rise?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can a person be righteous to God?
How can anyone born of a woman be pure?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the moon isn’t bright,
and the stars aren’t pure in his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less pure is a mortal—who is only a maggot—
a descendant of Adam—who is only a worm!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job replied to his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have helped the person who has no power
and saved the arm that isn’t strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have advised the person who has no wisdom
and offered so much assistance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To whom have you spoken these words,
and whose spirit has spoken through you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The souls of the dead tremble beneath the water,
and so do the creatures living there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol is naked in God’s presence,
and Abaddon has no clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He stretches out his heavens over empty space.
He hangs the earth on nothing whatsoever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He holds the water in his thick clouds,
and the clouds don’t even split under its weight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He covers his throne
by spreading his cloud over it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He marks the horizon on the surface of the water
at the boundary where light meets dark.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pillars of heaven tremble
and are astonished when he yells at them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With his power he calmed the sea.
With his insight he killed Rahab the sea monster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With his wind the sky was cleared.
With his hand he stabbed the fleeing snake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“These are only glimpses of what he does.
We only hear a whisper of him!
Who can understand the thunder of his power?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job continued his poems and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I swear an oath
by God, the one who has taken away my rights,
by the Almighty, who has made my life bitter:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘As long as there is one breath left in me
and God’s breath fills my nostrils,
speaker: Narrator

text:
my lips will not say anything wrong,
and my tongue will not mumble anything deceitful.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
It’s unthinkable for me to admit that you are right.
Until I breathe my last breath, I will never give up my claim of integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cling to my righteousness and won’t let go.
My conscience won’t accuse me as long as I live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let my enemy be treated like wicked people.
Let anyone who attacks me be treated like unrighteous people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After all, what hope does the godless person have when he is cut off,
when God takes away his life?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will God hear his cry when trouble comes upon him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can he be happy with the Almighty?
Can he call on God at all times?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will teach you about God’s power.
I will not hide what the Almighty has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, you have all seen it.
Why then do you chatter on about such nonsense?
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what God has waiting for the wicked person,
the inheritance that tyrants receive from the Almighty:
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he has many children, swords will kill them,
and his descendants won’t have enough food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who survive him will be buried by a plague,
and their widows won’t cry for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he collects silver like dust
and piles up clothing like dirt,
speaker: Narrator

text:
righteous people will wear what he piles up,
and the innocent will divide the silver among themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He builds his house like a moth,
like a shack that a watchman makes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He may go to bed rich, but he’ll never be rich again.
When he opens his eyes, nothing will be left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors overtake him like a flood.
A windstorm snatches him away at night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The east wind carries him away, and he’s gone.
It sweeps him from his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It hurls itself at him without mercy.
He flees from its power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It claps its hands over him.
It whistles at him from his own place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There is a place where silver is mined
and a place where gold is refined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iron is taken from the ground,
and rocks are melted for their copper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Humans bring an end to darkness there
and search to the limit of the gloomy, pitch-black rock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They open up a mineshaft far from civilization,
where no one has set foot.
In this shaft men dangle and swing back and forth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Above the ground food grows,
but beneath it the food decays as if it were burned by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That place’s stones are sapphire.
Its dust contains gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No bird of prey knows the way to it.
No hawk’s eye has ever seen it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No proud beast has ever walked on it.
No ferocious lion has ever passed over it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Humans exert their power on the flinty rocks
and overturn mountains at their base.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cut out mineshafts in the rocks.
Their eyes see every precious thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They explore the sources of rivers
so that they bring hidden treasures to light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where can wisdom be found?
Where does understanding live?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No mortal knows where it is.
It cannot be found in this world of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The deep ocean says, ‘It isn’t in me.’
The sea says, ‘It isn’t with me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
You cannot obtain it with solid gold
or buy it for any amount of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It can’t be bought with the gold from Ophir
or with precious onyx or sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Neither gold nor glass can equal its value.
Nor can gold ornaments, jewels, or crystal
speaker: Narrator

text:
be exchanged for it.
Wisdom is more valuable than gems.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Topaz from Ethiopia cannot equal its value.
It cannot be bought for any amount of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where does wisdom come from?
Where does understanding live?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is hidden from the eyes of every living being,
hidden even from the birds in the air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Decay and Death say,
‘We’ve heard a rumor about it.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God understands the way to it.
He knows where it lives
speaker: Narrator

text:
because he can see to the ends of the earth
and observe everything under heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he gave the wind its force
and measured the water in the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he made rules for the rain
and set paths for the thunderstorms,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he saw it and announced it.
He confirmed it and examined it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he told humans,
‘The fear of the Lord is wisdom!
To stay away from evil is understanding.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job continued his poems and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If only my life could be like it used to be,
in the days when God watched over me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he made his lamp shine on my head,
when I walked through the dark in his light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only I were in the prime of my life again,
when God was an adviser in my tent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Almighty was still with me
and my children were around me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
my steps were bathed in buttermilk,
and the rocks poured streams of olive oil on me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I went through the city gate
and took my seat in the town square,
speaker: Narrator

text:
young men saw me and kept out of sight.
Old men stood up straight out of respect for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Princes held back their words
and put their hands over their mouths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The voices of nobles were hushed,
and their tongues stuck to the roofs of their mouths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Any ears that heard me blessed me.
Any eyes that saw me spoke well of me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I rescued the poor who called for help
and the orphans who had no one to help them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I received a blessing from the dying.
I made the widow’s heart sing for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I put on righteousness, and it was my clothing.
I practiced justice, and it was my robe and my turban.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was eyes for the blind person.
I was feet for the lame person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was father to the needy.
I carefully investigated cases brought by strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I broke the teeth of the wicked person
and made him drop the prey out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I thought, ‘I may die in my own house,
but I will make my days as numerous as the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My roots will grow toward the water,
and dew will lie on my branches all night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My power will be fresh every day,
and the bow in my hand will remain new.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“People listened to me eagerly,
quietly waiting for my advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After I had spoken, they wouldn’t speak again.
After all, my words fell gently on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were as eager to hear me as they were for rain.
They opened their mouths wide as if waiting for a spring shower.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I smiled at them, they could hardly believe it,
but the expression on my face did not change.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I decided how they should live.
I sat as their leader.
I lived like a king among his troops,
like one who comforts mourners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now those who are younger than I am laugh at me.
I didn’t think their fathers were fit to sit with the dogs of my flock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Of what use to me was the strength of their hands?
Their strength is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shriveled up from need and hunger,
they gnaw at the dry and barren ground during the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They pick saltwort from the underbrush,
and the roots of the broom plant are their food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are driven from the community.
People shout at them in the same way they shout at thieves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have to live in dry riverbeds,
in holes in the ground, and among rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They howl in bushes
and huddle together under thornbushes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Godless fools and worthless people
are forced out of the land with whips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And now they make fun of me with songs.
I have become a joke to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Since they consider me disgusting, they keep their distance from me
and don’t hesitate to spit in my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because God has untied my cord and has made me suffer,
they are no longer restrained in my presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have attacked me on my right side like a mob.
They trip my feet
and then prepare ways to destroy me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, they remove all traces of my path in order to destroy me.
No one is there to help me against them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They come through a wide hole in the wall.
They crawl through the ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors are directed toward me.
They blow away my dignity like the wind.
My prosperity vanishes like a cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now my life is pouring out of me.
Days of suffering seize me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At night God pierces my bones.
My body doesn’t rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With great strength he grabs my clothes.
He seizes me by the collar of my robe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He throws me into the dirt
so that I become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I call to you for help,
but you don’t answer me.
I stand up, but you just look at me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have begun to treat me cruelly.
With your mighty hand you assault me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You pick me up and let the wind carry me away.
You toss me around with a storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know you will lead me to death,
to the dwelling place appointed for all living beings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But God doesn’t stretch out his hand against one who is ruined
when that person calls for help in his disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Didn’t I cry for the person whose days were difficult?
Didn’t my soul grieve for the poor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I waited for good, evil came.
When I looked for light, darkness came.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My insides are churning and won’t calm down.
Days of misery are ahead of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I walk in the dark without the sun.
I stand up in public and call for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m a brother to jackals
and a companion of ostriches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin turns dark and peels.
My body burns with fever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So my lyre is used for mourning
and my flute for loud weeping.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have made an agreement with my eyes.
Then how can I look with lust at a virgin?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What would God above do to me?
What would be my inheritance from the Almighty on high?
