speaker: Narrator

text:
Aren’t there catastrophes for wicked people
and disasters for those who do wrong?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doesn’t he see my ways
and count all my steps?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have walked with lies
or my feet have run after deception,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let God weigh me on honest scales,
and he will know I have integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my steps have left the proper path,
or my heart has followed the desire of my eyes,
or my hands are stained with sin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let someone else eat what I have planted,
and let my crops be uprooted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have been seduced by a woman
or I have secretly waited near my neighbor’s door,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my wife grind for another man,
and let other men kneel over her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That would be a scandal,
and that would be a criminal offense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It would be a fire that burns even in Abaddon.
It would uproot my entire harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have abused the rights of my servants, male or female,
when they have disagreed with me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then what could I do if God rises up?
If he examines me, how could I answer him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Didn’t he who made me in my mother’s belly make them?
Didn’t the same God form us in the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have refused the requests of the poor
or made a widow’s eyes stop looking for help,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or have eaten my food alone
without letting the orphan eat any of it….
speaker: Narrator

text:
(From my youth the orphan grew up with me
as though I were his father,
and from my birth I treated the widow kindly.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have seen anyone die because he had no clothes
or a poor person going naked….
speaker: Narrator

text:
(If his body didn’t bless me,
or the wool from my sheep didn’t keep him warm….)
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have shaken my fist at an orphan
because I knew that others would back me up in court,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my shoulder fall out of its socket,
and let my arm be broken at the elbow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“A disaster from God terrifies me.
In the presence of his majesty I can do nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I put my confidence in gold
or said to fine gold, ‘I trust you’….
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I enjoyed being very rich
because my hand had found great wealth….
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I saw the light shine
or the moon move along in its splendor
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that my heart was secretly tempted,
and I threw them a kiss with my hand,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then that, too, would be a criminal offense,
and I would have denied God above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I enjoyed the ruin of my enemy
or celebrated when harm came to him
speaker: Narrator

text:
(even though I didn’t speak sinfully
by calling down a curse on his life)….
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If the people who were in my tent had said,
‘We wish we had never filled our stomachs with his food’….
speaker: Narrator

text:
(The visitor never spent the night outside,
because I opened my door to the traveler.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have covered my disobedience like Adam
and kept my sin to myself,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I dreaded the large, noisy crowd
and because the contempt of the local mobs terrified me
so that I kept quiet and didn’t go outside….
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If only I had someone who would listen to me!
Look, here is my signature!
Let the Almighty answer me.
Let the prosecutor write his complaint on a scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would certainly carry it on my shoulder
and place it on my head like a crown.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would tell him the number of my steps
and approach him like a prince.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my land has cried out against me,
and its furrows have wept….
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have eaten its produce without paying for it
and made its owners breathe their last,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let it grow thistles instead of wheat,
and foul-smelling weeds instead of barley.”
This is the end of Job’s words.
speaker: Narrator

text: These three men stopped answering Job because Job thought he was righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elihu, son of Barachel, a descendant of Buz from the family of Ram, became very angry with Job because Job thought he was more righteous than God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu was also very angry with Job’s three friends because they had found no answer. They made it look as if God were wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu waited as they spoke to Job because they were older than he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elihu saw that the three men had no further responses, he became very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Elihu, son of Barachel, the descendant of Buz, replied to Job,
“I am young, and you are old.
That’s why I refrained from speaking
and was afraid to tell you what I know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I thought, ‘Age should speak,
and experience should teach wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, there is in humans a Spirit,
the breath of the Almighty, that gives them understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People do not become wise merely because they live long.
They don’t understand what justice is merely because they’re old.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That is why I say, ‘Listen to me!
Let me tell you what I know.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I waited for you to speak.
I listened for you to share your understanding
until you could find the right words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve paid close attention to you,
but none of you refuted Job.
None of you has an answer to what he says.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So don’t say, ‘We’ve found wisdom.
Let God, not humans, defeat him.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Job did not choose his words to refute me,
so I won’t answer him with your speeches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Job’s friends have been overwhelmed and don’t have any more answers.
They don’t have another word to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should I wait because they don’t speak,
because they stand there and don’t have any more answers?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ll give my answer.
I’ll tell you what I know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m full of words.
The Spirit within me forces me to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My belly is like a bottle of wine that has not been opened,
like new wineskins that are ready to burst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I must speak to get relief.
I must open my mouth and answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I won’t be partial toward anyone
or flatter anyone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I don’t know how to flatter.
If I did, my maker would soon carry me away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please, Job, listen to my words
and consider everything I say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve opened my mouth.
The words are on the tip of my tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My words are straight from the heart,
and I sincerely speak the knowledge that is on my lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God’s Spirit has made me.
The breath of the Almighty gives me life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer me if you can.
Present your case to me, and take your stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, I stand in front of God as you do.
I, too, was formed from a piece of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You certainly don’t need to be terrified of me.
I won’t put too much pressure on you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But you spoke directly to me,
and I listened to your words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You said, ‘I’m pure—without any rebellious acts against God.
I’m clean; I have no sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is only looking for an excuse to attack me.
He considers me his enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He puts my feet in the stocks and watches all my paths.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
You aren’t right about this!
I’ve got an answer for you:
God is greater than any mortal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you quarrel with him
since he doesn’t answer any questions?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God speaks in one way,
even in two ways without people noticing it:
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a dream, a prophetic vision at night,
when people fall into a deep sleep,
when they sleep on their beds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he opens people’s ears
and terrifies them with warnings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He warns them to turn away from doing wrong
and to stop being arrogant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He keeps their souls from the pit
and their lives from crossing the River of Death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In pain on their sickbeds, they are disciplined
with endless aching in their bones
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that their whole being hates food
and they lose their appetite for a delicious meal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their flesh becomes so thin that it can’t be seen.
Their bones, not seen before, will be exposed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their souls approach the pit.
Their lives come close to those already dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If they have a messenger for them,
a spokesman, one in a thousand,
to tell people what is right for them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he will have pity on them and say,
‘Free them from going into the pit.
I have found a ransom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then their flesh will become softer than a child’s.
They will go back to the days of their youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will pray to God, who will be pleased with them.
They will see God’s face and shout for joy
as he restores their righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Each one sings in front of other people and says,
‘I sinned and did wrong instead of what was right,
and it did me no good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The messenger has freed my soul from going into the pit,
and my life will see the light.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly, God does all this two or three times with people
speaker: Narrator

text:
to turn their souls away from the pit
and to enlighten them with the light of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Pay attention, Job! Listen to me!
Keep quiet, and let me speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have a response, answer me.
Speak, because I’d be happy if you were right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If not, you listen to me.
Keep quiet, and I’ll teach you wisdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu continued to speak to Job and his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen to my words, you wise men.
Open your ears to me, you intelligent men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ear tests words
like the tongue tastes food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let’s decide for ourselves what is right
and agree among ourselves as to what is good,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because Job has said,
‘I’m righteous, but God has taken away my rights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m considered a liar in spite of my rights.
I’ve been wounded by a deadly arrow,
though I haven’t been disobedient.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
What person is like Job,
who drinks scorn like water,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who travels with troublemakers
and associates with evil people?
speaker: Narrator

text: He says, ‘It doesn’t do any good to try to please God.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You people who have understanding, listen to me.
It is unthinkable that God would ever do evil
or that the Almighty would ever do wicked things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God will repay humanity for what it has done
and will give each person what he deserves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, God will never do anything evil,
and the Almighty will never pervert justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who put him in charge of the earth?
Who appointed him to be over the whole world?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he thought only of himself
and withdrew his Spirit and his breath,
speaker: Narrator

text:
all living beings would die together,
and humanity would return to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you understand, listen to this.
Open your ears to my words!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should anyone who hates justice be allowed to govern?
Will you condemn the one who is righteous and mighty?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should anyone even say to a king,
‘You good-for-nothing scoundrel!’
or to nobles, ‘You wicked people!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The one who is righteous and mighty
does not grant special favors to princes
or prefer important people over poor people
because his hands made them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die suddenly in the middle of the night.
People have seizures and pass away.
Mighty people are taken away but not by human hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God’s eyes are on a person’s ways.
He sees all his steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There’s no darkness or deep shadow
where troublemakers can hide.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t have to set a time for a person
in order to bring him to divine judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He breaks mighty people into pieces without examining them
and puts others in their places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He knows what they do,
so he overthrows them at night, and they’re crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text: In return for their evil, he strikes them in public,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they turned away from following him
and didn’t consider any of his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They forced the poor to cry out to him,
and he hears the cry of those who suffer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he keeps quiet, who can condemn him?
If he hides his face, who can see him
whether it is a nation or a single person?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does this so that godless people cannot rule
and so that they cannot trap people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But suppose such a person says to God, ‘I am guilty,
I will stop my immoral behavior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach me what I cannot see.
If I’ve done wrong, I won’t do it again.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should God reward you on your own terms since you have rejected his?
You must choose, not I.
Tell me what you know. Speak!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“People of understanding, the wise people
who listen to me, will say,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Job speaks without knowledge.
His words show no insight.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My Father, let Job be thoroughly tested
for giving answers like wicked people do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He adds disobedience to his sin.
He claps his hands to insult us.
He multiplies his words against God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu continued to speak to Job and his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you think this is right
when you say, ‘My case is more just than God’s,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
when you ask, ‘What benefit is it to you?’
and, ‘What would I gain by sinning?’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will answer you and your friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look at the heavens and see.
Observe the clouds high above you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you’ve sinned, what effect can you have on God?
If you’ve done many wrongs, what can you do to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you’re righteous, what can you give him,
or what can he get from you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your wickedness affects only someone like yourself.
Your righteousness affects only the descendants of Adam.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The weight of oppression makes them cry out.
The power of mighty people makes them call for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But no one asks,
‘Where is God, my Creator,
who inspires songs in the night,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who teaches us more than he teaches the animals of the earth,
who makes us wiser than the birds in the sky?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they cry out, but he doesn’t answer them
because of the arrogance of those evil people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely, God doesn’t listen to idle complaints.
The Almighty doesn’t even pay attention to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although you say that you pay attention to him,
your case is in front of him, but you’ll have to wait for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now you say that his anger doesn’t punish anyone
and he isn’t too concerned about evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Job opens his mouth for no good reason
and talks a lot without having any knowledge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu continued to speak to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Be patient with me a little longer, and I will show you
that there is more to be said in God’s defense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will get my knowledge from far away
and prove that my Creator is fair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, my words are not lies.
The one who knows everything is speaking with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Certainly, God is mighty.
He doesn’t despise anyone.
He is mighty and brave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t allow the wicked person to live.
He grants justice to those who are oppressed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He doesn’t take his eyes off righteous people.
He seats them on thrones with kings to honor them forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, if righteous people are bound in chains
and tangled in ropes of misery,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he tells them what they’ve done wrong
and that they’ve behaved arrogantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes them listen to his warning
and orders them to turn away from wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If righteous people listen and serve him,
they will live out their days in prosperity
and their years in comfort.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if they don’t listen,
they will cross the River of Death
and die like those who have no knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But those who have godless hearts remain angry.
They don’t even call for help when he chains them up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die while they’re young,
or they live on as male prostitutes in the temples of idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rescues suffering people through their suffering,
and he opens their ears through distress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yes, he lured you away from the jaws of trouble
into an open area where you were not restrained,
and your table was covered with rich foods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you are given the judgment evil people deserve.
A fair judgment will be upheld.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be careful that you are not led astray with riches.
Don’t let a large bribe turn you to evil ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your riches save you from having to suffer?
Will all your mighty strength help you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t look forward to the night,
when people disappear from their places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be careful! Don’t turn to evil,
because you have chosen evil instead of suffering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God does great things by his power.
Is there any teacher like him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can tell him which way he should go?
Who can say to him, ‘You did wrong’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember that you should praise his work.
People have sung about it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every person has seen it.
Mortals have looked at it from a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Certainly, God is so great
that he is beyond our understanding.
The number of his years cannot be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He collects drops of water.
He distills rain from his mist,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which then drips from the clouds.
It pours down on many people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can anyone really understand how clouds spread out
or how he thunders from his dwelling place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, he scatters his flashes of lightning around him
and covers the depths of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is how he uses the rains to provide for people
and to give them more than enough food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He fills his hands with lightning
and orders it to hit the target.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The thunder announces his coming.
The storm announces his angry wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My heart pounds because of this
and jumps out of its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen! Listen to the roar of God’s voice,
to the rumbling that comes from his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He flashes his lightning everywhere under heaven.
His light flashes to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is followed by the roar of his voice.
He thunders with his majestic voice.
He doesn’t hold the lightning back when his thunder is heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God’s voice thunders in miraculous ways.
It does great things that we cannot understand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He says to the snow, ‘Fall to the ground,’
and to the pouring rain, ‘Rain harder!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes it impossible to do anything 
so that people will recognize his work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Animals go into their dens
and stay in their lairs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A storm comes out of its chamber.
It is cold because of the strong winds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God’s breath produces ice,
and the seas freeze over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, he loads the thick clouds with moisture
and scatters his lightning from the clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He guides the clouds as they churn round and round
over the face of the inhabited earth
to do everything he orders them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whether for discipline,
or for the good of his earth,
or out of mercy,
he makes the storm appear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Open your ears to this, Job.
Stop and consider God’s miracles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know how God controls them
and makes the lightning flash from his clouds?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know how the clouds drift
(these are the miracles of the one who knows everything),
speaker: Narrator

text:
you whose clothes are hot and sweaty,
when the earth is calm under a south wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you stretch out the skies with him
and make them as firm as a mirror made of metal?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach us what we should say to him.
We are unable to prepare a case because of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should he be told that I want to speak?
Can a person speak when he is confused?
speaker: Narrator

text:
People can’t look at the sun
when it’s bright among the clouds
or after the wind has blown and cleared those clouds away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A golden light comes from the north.
A terrifying majesty is around God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Almighty, whom we can’t reach,
is great in power and judgment,
has more than enough righteousness,
and does not oppress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why people should fear him.
He does not respect those who think they’re wise.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is this that belittles my advice
with words that do not show any knowledge about it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Brace yourself like a man!
I will ask you, and you will teach me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where were you when I laid the foundation of the earth?
Tell me if you have such insight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who determined its dimensions?
Certainly, you know!
Who stretched a measuring line over it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On what were its footings sunk?
Who laid its cornerstone
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the morning stars sang together
and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who shut the sea behind gates
when it burst through and came out of the womb,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I clothed it with clouds
and wrapped it up in dark clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I set a limit for it
and put up bars and gates,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I said, ‘You may come this far but no farther.
Here your proud waves will stop’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you ever given orders to the morning
or assigned a place for the dawn
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that it could grab the earth by its edges
and shake wicked people out of it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth changes like clay stamped by a seal,
and parts of it stand out like folds in clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wicked people are deprived of their light,
and an arm raised in victory is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you gone to the springs in the sea
or walked through the valleys of the ocean depths?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gateways to death been revealed to you,
or have you seen the gateways to total darkness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you even considered how wide the earth is?
Tell me, if you know all of this!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is the way to the place where light lives?
Where is the home of darkness
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that you may lead it to its territory,
so that you may know the path to its home?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You must know because you were born then
and have lived such a long time!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you been to the warehouses where snow is stored
or seen the warehouses for hail
speaker: Narrator

text:
that I have stored up for the time of trouble,
for the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which is the way to the place where light is scattered
and the east wind is spread across the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who made a channel for the flooding rains
and a path for the thunderstorms
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring rain on a land where no one lives,
on a desert where there are no humans,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to saturate the desolate wasteland
in order to make it sprout with grass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does the rain have a father?
Who gave birth to the dewdrops?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From whose womb came the ice,
and who has given birth to the frost in the air?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The water hardens like a stone,
and the surface of the ocean freezes over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you connect the chains of the constellation Pleiades
or untie the ropes of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you bring out the constellations at the right time
or guide Ursa Major with its cubs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the laws of the sky
or make them rule the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you call to the clouds
and have a flood of water cover you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you send lightning flashes so that they may go and say to you,
‘Here we are’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who put wisdom in the heart
or gave understanding to the mind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is wise enough to count the clouds
or pour out the water jars of heaven
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the dirt hardens into clumps
and the soil clings together?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you hunt prey for the lioness
and satisfy the hunger of her cubs
speaker: Narrator

text:
as they crouch in their dens
and lie ready to ambush from their lairs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who provides food for the crow
when its young ones cry to God
and wander around in need of food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know the time when the mountain goats give birth?
Do you watch the does when they are in labor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you count the months they are pregnant
or know the time when they’ll give birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They kneel down to give birth and deliver their young.
Then the pain of giving birth is over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their young are healthy and grow up in the wild.
They leave and don’t come back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who lets the wild donkey go free?
Who unties the ropes of the wild donkey?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I gave it the desert to live in
and the salt flats as its dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It laughs at the noise of the city
and doesn’t even listen to the shouting of its master.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It explores the mountains for its pasture
and looks for anything green.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will the wild ox agree to serve you,
or will it stay at night beside your feeding trough?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you guide a wild ox in a furrow,
or will it plow the valleys behind you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you trust it just because it’s so strong
or leave your labor to it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you rely on it to bring your grain back
and take it to your threshing floor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Does the ostrich flap its wings in joy,
or do its wings lack feathers?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It lays its eggs on the ground
and warms them in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It forgets that a foot may crush them
or a wild animal may trample them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It acts harshly toward its young as if they weren’t its own.
It is not afraid that its work is for nothing
speaker: Narrator

text:
because God has deprived it of wisdom
and did not give it any understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: It laughs at the horse and its rider when it gets up to flee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you give strength to a horse
or dress its neck with a flowing mane?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you make it leap like a locust,
when its snorting causes terror?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It paws in strength and finds joy in its power.
It charges into battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It laughs at fear,
is afraid of nothing,
and doesn’t back away from swords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A quiver of arrows rattles on it
along with the flashing spear and javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anxious and excited, the horse eats up the ground
and doesn’t trust the sound of the ram’s horn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As often as the horn sounds, the horse says, ‘Aha!’
and it smells the battle far away—
the thundering orders of the captains and the battle cries.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Does your understanding make a bird of prey fly
and spread its wings toward the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it by your order that the eagle flies high
and makes its nest on the heights?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It perches for the night on a cliff.
Its fortress is on a jagged peak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there it seeks food,
and its eyes see it from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its young ones feed on blood. It is found wherever there are dead bodies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord responded to Job,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will the person who finds fault with the Almighty correct him?
Will the person who argues with God answer him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job answered the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’m so insignificant. How can I answer you?
I will put my hand over my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I spoke once, but I can’t answer—
twice, but not again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord responded to Job out of a storm,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Brace yourself like a man!
I will ask you, and you will teach me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Would you undo my justice?
Would you condemn me so that you can be righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you have power like God’s?
Can you thunder with a voice like his?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then dress yourself in majesty and dignity.
Clothe yourself in splendor and glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unleash your outbursts of anger.
Look at all who are arrogant, and put them down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at all who are arrogant, and humble them.
Crush wicked people wherever they are.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide them completely in the dust,
and cover their faces in the hidden place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then even I will praise you
because your right hand can save you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look at Behemoth, which I made along with you.
It eats grass as cattle do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at the strength in its back muscles,
the power in its stomach muscles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It makes its tail stiff like a cedar.
The ligaments of its thighs are intertwined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its bones are bronze tubes.
They are like iron bars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behemoth is the first of God’s conquests.
Its maker approaches it with his sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hills bring it food,
and all the wild animals play there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It lies down under the lotus plants
in a hiding place among reeds and swamps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lotus plants provide it with cover.
Poplars by the stream surround it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though the river flows powerfully against it, it’s not alarmed.
It’s confident even when the Jordan rushes against its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can anyone blind its eyes 
or pierce its nose with snares?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you pull Leviathan out of the water with a fishhook
or tie its tongue down with a rope?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you put a ring through its nose
or pierce its jaw with a hook?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it plead with you for mercy
or speak tenderly to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it make an agreement with you
so that you can take it as your permanent slave?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you play with it like a bird
or keep it on a leash for your girls?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will traders bargain over it
and divide it among the merchants?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you fill its hide with harpoons
or its head with fishing spears?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay your hand on it.
Think of the struggle!
Don’t do it again!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, any hope of defeating it is a false hope.
Doesn’t the sight of it overwhelm you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one is brave enough to provoke Leviathan.
Then who can stand in front of me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can confront me that I should repay him?
Everything under heaven belongs to me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will not be silent about Leviathan’s limbs,
its strength, or its graceful form.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can skin its hide?
Who can approach it with a harness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can open its closed mouth?
Its teeth are surrounded by terror.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its back has rows of scales that are tightly sealed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One is so close to the other
that there is no space between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Each is joined to the other.
They are locked together and inseparable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Leviathan sneezes, it gives out a flash of light.
Its eyes are like the first rays of the dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Flames shoot from its mouth.
Sparks of fire fly from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Smoke comes from its nostrils
like a boiling pot heated over brushwood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its breath sets coals on fire,
and a flame pours from its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strength resides in its neck,
and power dances in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The folds of its flesh stick to each other.
They are solid and cannot be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its chest is solid like a rock,
solid like a millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The mighty are afraid when Leviathan rises.
Broken down, they draw back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A sword may strike it but not pierce it.
Neither will a spear, lance, or dart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It considers iron to be like straw
and bronze to be like rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An arrow won’t make it run away.
Stones from a sling turn to dust against it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It considers clubs to be like stubble,
and it laughs at a rattling javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its underside is like sharp pieces of broken pottery.
It stretches out like a threshing  sledge on the mud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It makes the deep sea boil like a pot.
It stirs up the ocean like a boiling kettle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It leaves a shining path behind it
so that the sea appears to have silvery hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nothing on land can compare to it.
It was made fearless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It looks down on all high things.
It is king of everyone who is arrogant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I know that you can do everything
and that your plans are unstoppable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You said, ‘Who is this that belittles my advice
without having any knowledge about it?’
Yes, I have stated things I didn’t understand,
things too mysterious for me to know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You said, ‘Listen now, and I will speak.
I will ask you, and you will teach me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I had heard about you with my own ears,
but now I have seen you with my own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why I take back what I said,
and I sit in dust and ashes to show that I am sorry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Lord had said those things to Job, the Lord said to Eliphaz from Teman, “I’m very angry with you and your two friends because you didn’t speak what is right about me as my servant Job has done.
speaker: Narrator

text: So take seven young bulls and seven rams. Go to my servant Job, and make a burnt offering for yourselves. My servant Job will pray for you. Then I will accept his prayer not to treat you as godless fools. After all, you didn’t speak what is right about me as my servant Job has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz of Teman, Bildad of Shuah, and Zophar of Naama went and did what the Lord had told them to do. And the Lord accepted Job’s prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Job prayed for his friends, the Lord restored Job’s prosperity and gave him twice as much as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all his brothers and sisters and everyone who had previously known him came to him. They ate with him at his house, sympathized with him, and comforted him for all the evil the Lord had brought to him. Each one gave him some money and a gold ring.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord blessed the latter years of Job’s life more than the earlier years. He had 14,000 sheep and goats, 6,000 camels, 2,000 oxen, and 1,000 donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: He named the first daughter Jemimah, the second Cassia, and the third Keren Happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nowhere in the whole country could be found women who were as beautiful as Job’s daughters. Their father gave them and their brothers an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job lived 140 years after this. He saw his children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then at a very old age, Job died.
speaker: Narrator
